To illustrate the potential severity of the problem described above, and preview the contributions of this paper, consider the following simple example. Let c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} be two clients with distinct data distributions. A server aims to optimize the function F​(𝐰)=p1​F1​(𝐰)+p2​F2​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰subscript𝑝1subscript𝐹1𝐰subscript𝑝2subscript𝐹2𝐰F(\mathbf{w})=p_{1}F_{1}(\mathbf{w})+p_{2}F_{2}(\mathbf{w}) over ℝpsuperscriptℝ𝑝\mathbb{R}^{p}, where F1subscript𝐹1F_{1} and F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} denote the loss functions at clients c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2}, respectively, and for simplicity p1=p2=1/2subscript𝑝1subscript𝑝212p_{1}=p_{2}=1/2. We shall consider a model for the clients’ intermittent availability characterized by the joint distributions given in Table 1,
where Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i} is a binary random variable indicating whether client cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} is available. In this model, clients’ availabilities in a given round are independent, with P​(A1=1)=0.375𝑃subscript𝐴110.375P(A_{1}=1)=0.375 while P​(A2=1)=0.8𝑃subscript𝐴210.8P(A_{2}=1)=0.8.
Note the client availabilities are assumed to be independent across rounds. Suppose there is a communication constraint which restricts the server to sampling at most a single client each round. The server must thus choose a possibly client state dependent policy for selecting the clients in each round. Each such policy would achieve certain long-term client participation rates across the rounds, denoted 𝐫=(r1,r2)𝐫subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2\mathbf{r}=(r_{1},r_{2}). For example, under the model in Table 1, the set of achievable long-term participation rates across all possible policies is given by the region ℛ1subscriptℛ1\mathcal{R}_{1} shown in Figure 1. Given the communication constraints, it is not possible to achieve the full client participation rates of 𝐫=(1,1)𝐫11\mathbf{r}=(1,1) because clients are not always available and we can only sample one client in each round. However, 𝐫a=(0.375,0)superscript𝐫𝑎0.3750\mathbf{r}^{a}=(0.375,0) is achievable by using the state-dependent deterministic policy which selects c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} whenever c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} is available and never selects c2subscript𝑐2c_{2}. Alternatively, 𝐫b=(0.375,0.5)superscript𝐫𝑏0.3750.5\mathbf{r}^{b}=(0.375,0.5) is also achievable by selecting c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} whenever c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} is available, and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} when only c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} is available. A naive selection policy that samples from available clients with probability proportional to pi=12subscript𝑝𝑖12p_{i}=\frac{1}{2} in hope of achieving “ideal” participation rate (12,12)1212(\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}) [22] would actually result in client c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} participating at a rate of

FedAvg 0.529 0.534 0.512 0.525 0.526

references: presents average user and sample loss over CIFAR100 and Shakespeare for all availability models. User average first computes the local test metric and then averages over users, while sample metrics computes the metric averaged over all test samples. Typically in deep learning test sample accuracy reflects better performance. However, in federated learning uniform performance across users is desired even if some users have very few datapoints. Below we show that claims in
are also valid for user-averaged metrics. Notice that sample accuracy and user accuracy coincide in CIFAR100 given that data is split in a balanced way among clients so we omit these results.
